awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Reusable Adhesive Fasteners Using Shape Memory Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to address the critical market pain points and demand for damage-free, yet secure and repeatedly usable adhesive fasteners that can perform well on both dry and wet surfaces. This project develops a reusable adhesive fastener that is a non-tacky, quickly-reversible adhesive, exhibiting high joining strength and reversibility. Due to the unique mechanism the device uses to toggle its adhesion, this device leaves the underlying surface damage-free.  The fastener is easily removable, repeatedly usable, and potentially will have low manufacturing costs. Such an adhesive fastener enables the user to easily and securely mount and dismount moderately heavy objects without the risk of damaging or leaving residue on the mounting surface, even on moderately porous and rough surfaces.  Furthermore, since the adhesive fastener is water-resistant, high-performance fastening can also be applied in wet environments, expanding the potential market applications.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will demonstrate an adhesive fastener that works with high reliability and durability in diverse environmental conditions, with effective activation methods.  Shape memory polymer (SMP) formulations and the mechanics at the adhesive contact interface will be optimized to make the  fastener more resistant to contact failure. Since the adhesive contact failure mode of this adhesive fastener is typically fracture, there will be significant efforts on refining the mechanical design to retard adhesive contact fracture, and the resulting performance in terms of joining strength and duration will be quantitatively determined. An optimized fabrication process for conductive SMPs will be developed by incorporating conductive fillers into the SMP material to enable continuous production, ensuring uniform product quality and enabling scalable manufacturing. For this purpose, the effective Joule-heating, shape memory effect, and final reversible adhesive properties of the conductive SMP upon conductive filler composition, concentration, and spatial concentration configuration will be investigated. The adhesive performance in wet conditions of the SMP will be demonstrated and systematically tested to minimum performance standards under a variety of liquid types and thermomechanical loading conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In Respondic Inc.?s Phase I project, we developed a reusable, damage-free fastening technology using a type of polymer called shape memory polymers (SMPs). SMPs can switch back and forth between soft and rigid states with the addition or removal of heat energy. When the polymer is above its glass transition temperature, the polymer is soft, and when below its glass transition temperature, the polymer is rigid. The adhesion is made through the net effect of a microscopic force called the van der Waals force, which is the same mechanism insects utilize to climb walls. The van der Waals force in itself is considered a relatively weak intermolecular bond; however, when the adhesive contact area can be maximized at the microstructure level of the target surface, a high collective adhesion strength can be achieved. The contact area is maximized by pressing down on the polymer when it is in its soft and heated state, allowing the polymer surface to fill the microscopic grooves and cavities of the target surface. The polymer is then cooled down, allowing the shape memory effect to lock this temporary deformed shape that mirrors the target surface?s microstructure. The van der Waals force that the adhesive mechanism utilizes is an electromagnetic bond, so there are no chemicals or liquids involved in the bonding. Furthermore, because the shape-change property of the polymer is reversible, the polymer adhesive is reusable.

The experimental results showed adhesive strengths that exceeded 5 atm (about 73 lbs per square inch) on all surfaces tested, in both normal and shear loading directions. Long-term adhesive performance was also demonstrated by testing the same SMP adhesive sample on 100 consecutive tests and concluding that the surface did not display degradation in adhesive capabilities. Testing for reversibility showed that the adhesive can be easily removed despite displaying a high adhesion strength during fastening. The tests on the dual-stiffness SMP samples also showed that adhesion can be further improved (nearly doubled) by combining and arranging soft and rigid SMPs on the adhesive surface in a way to significantly enhance its mechanical response to loads. The tests performed on tap water and sea water showed high adhesion strength is still maintained even when adhesion is performed in submerged or wet conditions, demonstrating that SMP adhesive products will be effectively waterproof in standard usage conditions as a product. Finally, the potential for SMPs to be internally heated instead of through an external heater was confirmed through experimental tests on SMP materials that had electrically-conductive filler materials embedded onto it.

The results of this project show that SMP adhesives can demonstrate high reliability and durability in diverse environmental conditions with effective activation methods while being reusable and easily-removed. SMP formulations and the mechanics at the adhesive contact interface have been successfully optimized to make Respondic's adhesive fastener more resistant to contact failure for reliable and durable adhesive fastening. Furthermore, conductive SMPs have been developed in this project, enabling the potential for continuous production, not only for uniform product quality but also for scalable manufacturing.

Respondic?s SMP adhesive technology was derived from research conducted at the University of Illinois in academia prior to the formation of the company. This project contributed to furthering this research and understanding of SMPs by investigating its market potential and through the development of Respondic?s minimum viable product, showing the potential of SMPs as a usable, practical product. Respondic also sponsored a market research project in Fall of 2020 through the UIUC GIES College of Business Action Learning program, which allowed four business students to apply their course materials to real-world contexts.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: John Seo
